title_sort: louisa van velsor whitman to walt whitman, [29 august 1865]
title: Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, [29 August 1865]
text: 29 Aug1865tuesdayTuesday eveningDear Walti have not gone to burlingtonBurlington yet but if nothing occurs i shall go next mondayMonday i have not felt able to go through the hot weather but as it is cooler now i think i can stand it i wish Walter you would write to hanna and tell her i will come on mondayMonday next if nothing prevents George thinks he will go as far as troyTroy and then come for me when i return) which will be before very long george will go to mrs hegamensHegeman's to board and edd will stay here marthaMartha has very much to doodo she has been foolish enoughfenough to take 2 or 300 dozens of shirt fronts and she cantcan't get them stichedstitched every girl is full of work so she and jeffJeff has set up every night till midnight to work i think she will be perfectly satisfied when she gets this lot done to not take any more sis almost lives down here, she thinks very much of orgee as she calls her unkleuncle georgeGeorge i suppose you got JeffsJeff's letter saying about George wanting to get in the custom house he would like to get in i suppose very much he and A man by the name of smithSmith has been talking of buying some lots and building A shop and 2 houses but he says that would not prevent him from going in the custom house if he could get the appointementappointment he seems to feel as if he ought to be earning something i dontdon't ask for but very little but he would give me if i asked for it i know. but i thingthink he wants to doodo something with what money there is) of course you know Walt i wouldentwouldn't make any fuss about it he has earned it hard and it rightly belongs to him and if he can doodo better with taking i would rather he would if i only had some place to live i am very tired of living here it is very disagreabledisagreeable in many ways GeorgGeorge thinks maybeemaybe we can get some small house but rents is so very high well i gessguess i wont worry i dontdon't believe i shall ever want i hope you will keep well walt i was glad to hear you boarded with mrs gracon i should think it would be much better) i have fixed up georgesGeorge's room and put a carpet in so he can take his friends up when he has them come) i want you Walt to send me a little change this week as you have done heretofore and when i get to hansHan's i wish you would send me five or six dollars at different times about two dollars at a time i may want to get some little things for her i believe i have said all i want tooto i have heard nothing from poor Jess and as to AndrewsAndrew's children Jimmy brings them up here sometimes poor little objects of misery they live i give them things when they come no more your motherLWthose criticisms on the press are all right Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, [29 August 1865]
